awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Evolution of Winds in Dust Disks Around Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
Planets formed from material in disks of gas and dust that once surrounded the stars they orbit. The way that these disks form and how material is spread throughout the disks affect both how quickly material is added to the stars themselves and what types of planets can form in the disks. Disk winds play a major role in the way this material is dispersed. In this study, the investigators build on their earlier work where they observed the disk winds in 33 disks. They observed two parts to the winds: a wind driven by magnetic/electric interactions and a wind driven by temperature differences. With this grant the investigators will extend their study to include a large number of much older disks with the goals of measuring how much the magnetic/electric process drives with wind and how much the thermal heating drives the wind. This project serves the national interest as it expands our understanding of the science behind the formation of planetary systems around other stars. A graduate student, a postdoc, and at least three undergraduate students will participate in this study. The investigators will also participate in a K-12 teacher workshop at The University of Arizona, reaching Hispanic and Native American communities. A two-week long astronomy class will be taught to high school girls from around the world in the annual Smith Summer Science and Engineering Program. 

The analysis of optical [OI] emission lines for the 33 disks in Taurus reveals two low-velocity kinematic components, one of which (broad component) likely traces a magnetohydrodynamic (MHD)-driven wind while the other (narrow component) might be associated with a thermally-driven wind. The investigators will establish empirically how disk winds evolve by measuring the relative proportion of MHD-driven and thermally-driven winds. They will also measure wind mass loss rates through the main stages of disk evolution and dispersal. They will extend their analysis of the [OI] lines to a sample of more evolved disks, including more disks with dust cavities, and analyze one of the blue [SII] transitions to clarify the thermal contribution to the [OI] emission.

por.por_cntn:
All stars are birthed surrounded by flattened, spinning protoplanetary disks. The diversity of known exoplanets will eventually be traced back to the diversity of youthful protoplanetary disks. These disks evolve and dissipate by a number of processes and this proposal was designed to look at one of these processes: winds emerging directly from the disk as it is forming planets. We are studying regions too small to be directly imaged and thus our exploration tool is high resolution spectroscopy, where velocities and line ratios can be used to determine that low velocity winds are definitely  emerging from protoplanetary disks, over a wide range of disk radii from near the star out to tens of astronomical units. Moreover, the winds in the inner disk are faster than those in the outer disk, and carry more mass out into space. The majority of the systems we looked at are best explained by winds that extract angular momentum via the magnetic field of the disk as they are flung outwards. Some older ones however likely arise from thermal pressure in a disk heated by high energy photons from the star. While there is more to be clarified about how these disk winds evolve in time, we have shown that the fast inner wind disappears more quickly than the slower outer wind. Ultimately we aim to relate the properties of protoplanetary disks to the types of planets that emerge from them.
